im testing this small change which seams to allow most test to pass. i only got 4 failures.

- p groups tests by class when executing them in parralel and --random asigns them to workers randomly instead of in alpabetical order. we have no timing data so it falls back to alpabetical order but i think random will give us better parallelisuim.
 

diff --git a/tox.ini b/tox.ini
index 56cf9fa6b4..ad2ebd7d84 100644
--- a/tox.ini
+++ b/tox.ini
@@ -142,7 +142,8 @@ setenv =
 deps = {[testenv:functional]deps}
 commands =
   coverage erase
-  stestr --test-path=./nova/tests/ run {posargs}
+  # - means ignore exit code we dont care if a test failed just that it ran.
+  - stestr -p --test-path=./nova/tests/ run --random {posargs}
   coverage combine
   coverage report

this is needed even if we are using the new coverage
binary or we will not get any coverage data for the test runs.

TL;DR feel free to drop --random

--random is proably not needed i think i was getting slightly better run times but well its random so im not sure.

since there is no timeing data in the vms by defualt it would be allocating the test groups to workers in alphabetical order near the end of the run this was causeing the test execution to slow down.

this still happens with --random but over all it seam better but in the gate it proably will make no difference. i was still seeing 3-4 thread active witout it near the end and in the gate that would be most of the cores

its only noticable locally becasue i had 24 cores working on it and without it i seamed to end up with 1 or 2 thread proceeing the last few tests. but i also saw that in some runs of this locally becasue random.

i dont think stester or coverage are respecitng OS_TEST_TIME

i had one case where i had a test that hung and it did not get killed after 30 second so just added a 10 minute timeout
looking at the gate times now that is proably way to short
i was runing with 24 cores the gate uses 8 and takes about 3 times as long which makes sense so we proably want to trile this to 1800 this should not be needed but i would like to get some result if a test hangs instead of throwing away all the data

this groups test by class when executing them in parallel

this seems to remove most if not all the issues we were seeing.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: how will this algorithm adjust counts[s][constants.PLATFORM_FUNCTION] when it is changed to Isolated?
For clarity this work the same way as assigning vswitch or shared cores. I think most of this code is redundant, but I don't have time to refactor it before this code needs to go in.

this is not quite accurate.  The cores that we tell kubernetes are reserved must be contiguous.  This includes platform cores, isolated cores, and vswitch cores.

This means we can't allocate any of these three types of cores on the second numa node until all the cores of the first numa node are configured as one of these three types.
For the isolated cores kubernetes will grab the first x cores in order. So they need to be contiguous. System reserved (platform cores) can come before it, but nothing else.

> Should be: Processor 0

I dislike this "Processor" stuff, since what we really care about is NUMA node, which is distinct from "socket" or "processor".  But I'm just being grumpy. :)

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
This is a bug.  I got a strange result, got the following error.
2019-09-19T02:38:37.355 controller-0 kubelet[144097]: info F0919 02:38:37.355570  144097 server.go:273] failed to run Kubelet: cannot reserve "--kube-reserved" resource

This was result of the following garbled args: /etc/sysconfig/kubelet:
KUBELET_EXTRA_ARGS=--node-ip=192.168.204.3 --cpu-manager-policy=static --system-reserved-cgroup=/system.slice --system-reserved=--kube-reserved=cpu=0cpu=4,--kube-reserved=cpu=0memory=7600Mi

This code is missing an ")" on the memory line, and that closing parenthesis got moved to the last line.  It should look like this instead:

    $k8s_cpu_manager_opts = join([
      '--cpu-manager-policy=static',
      '--system-reserved-cgroup=/system.slice',
      join([
        '--system-reserved=',
        "cpu=${k8s_reserved_cpus},",
        "memory=${k8s_reserved_mem}Mi"]),
      join([
        '--kube-reserved=',
        "cpu=${k8s_isol_cpus}"])
      ], ' ')

In theory when k8s_isol_cpus is 0, we don't need to print this option, but it doesn't seem to hurt.

placement/wsgi.py.message:
Oh, maybe this is why.

I think it's worth noting that it's a little dangerous to access another project's opts this way. If oslo.policy were to move/remove/rename this opt I'm pretty sure it would break placement.

Do you mean using policy_opts.set_defaults or using the enforce_scope option specifically?

For the latter, this is why we hit it:

https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/10146978ea2d7eace1ffdf6552eafd22360e37dd/placement/deploy.py#L117

Otherwise we get a ton of warnings. Maybe there is a better way to handle that though.

Oh, I see. enforce_scope actually makes the warnings into exceptions: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/4d40252748bd31584f1cbb72d4641dec62cf1303/oslo_policy/policy.py#L946

I wonder if we should provide a way for services to tell oslo.policy that they're not scope-enabled yet and have it suppress the warning in that case. There's not a lot of benefit to warning people about something they already know. I suppose there's a danger of forgetting to turn the suppression off after the migration to scope, but that applies to the method used here too.

Looking at enforce_scope specifically. The name of the opt on the conf object doesn't go through a deprecation process because it's assumed that only the project which defines the opt is looking at it, and they presumably would have updated all of their references when they deprecated it.

I also wonder if suppressing the warnings is the right thing to do. If the placement policy isn't ready to enforce scope, then turning that on is probably a bug. I strongly suspect that enforce_scope with non-scope-enabled policy rules would result in some undesired behavior. Hence the warning.

In any case, it's an existing issue that's only tangentially related to your change so it shouldn't block this IMHO.

I think the issue (from I34e4e550c9c31a654308e555210588156418f9e3) was that even when enforce_scope is False (which it is by default) we'd still get warnings in the logs which was annoying b/c we weren't enforcing scope. Arguably that's a bug in oslo.policy.

manila/tests/db/sqlalchemy/test_api.py.message: you're shadowing a python builtin called "filter". Perhaps rename this "filters"

To prove offset is working, I would try to retrieve the other shares and assert that the IDs of the other shares aren't there in this result.. 

  filters = {'limit': offset, 'offset': 0}
  shares_not_requested = db_api.share_get_all(self.ctxt, filters=filters)

  filters = {'limit': limit, 'offset': offset}
  shares_requested = db_api.share_get_all(self.ctxt, filters=filters)

 

  shares_not_requested_ids = [s['id'] for s in shares_not_requested]
  shares_requested_ids = [s['id'] for s in shares_requested]

 

  self.assertEqual(offset, len(shares_not_requested_ids))
  self.assertEqual(limit, len(shares_requested_ids))
  self.assertEqual(0, len(set(shares_requested_ids) & set(shares_requested_ids))

If I keep as it was, it was ever going to retrieve the results in the same order and the shares_requested and shares_not_requested lists were having equal items. In this way, I'm also able to do another thing you just suggested (check if the ids of the other shares are not there in the results).

Please make the example consistent throughout. Specifically:

It's confusing that `ns3` is 6GB in size, but `ns3` is used for `SMALL`, and ns0-2 are labeled `6GB`.

Please have the output of ndctl -X (L82) include at least an abbreviated version of all the namespaces used in the example. Use '...' to elide most of the content, like:

 {
     ...
     "size":1048576,
     ...
     "name":ns0,
     ...
 },
 etc.

'SMALL' and '6GB' are both $LABEL configured, they are just a string which help to distinguish different vpmem resources (not very related to real size), but I believe admin will not configure the namespaces like this to confuse themselfs.

nova is not a good example of how to use privsep corerctly.

in nova generic prialadged fucntion are groups into a privsep module and called from different parts fo the code.

this is an antipattern and we should not follow that in cyborg. the better approch is to place privadged fuction in the same module as the code that uses them.

mark all privaldges function with privaldge in there name.

that does not mean you cannot reuse the same privileged function form multiple places but they should not be grouped together

e.g.
"import cyborg.privsep.lspci as lspci" is bad as it hide the fact the function is eleveatd. in calling code it will just be lspci and you will not see it is privileged

the correct design is to do the following 

"from cyborg.pci import lspci_privileged"

this way calling code always know if a function is privileged or not.

this is way to many capablities.

you ideally should have multiple privsep context.

currently cybog does not do any networking so there is no reason for CAP_NET_ADMIN

with the curren set you can read/write/execution any file as well as modify networking and other namespcase. this is effectivly full root acess and is not secure at all.

file capablities

system capabilities.

you could make the above more readable using a combination of short-circuiting and different variable names:

 try:

     return None
 vif_addr = vif_pci_dev_address

 # Find PCIDevice associated with vif_pci_dev_address on the compute

     if dev.compute_node_id == cn_id and dev.address == vif_addr:

         break

     return None

 # Find PCIRequest associated with the given PCIDevice in instance
 for req in instance.pci_requests.requests:
     if req.request_id == found_dev.request_id:
         return req

 raise exception.PciRequestFromVIFNotFound(
     pci_slot=vif_pci_dev_address,
     node_id=compute_node.id)

After reading of commit topic and before reading change it was unclear for me what plugin is meant here. We have following "things" that are used in conjunction with word "plugin":

- devstack plugin
- tempest plugin
- plugin mechanism for share drivers
- network plugin mechanism

So, to reduce ambiguity, please, mention here devstack. For example:

"""
Update readme file with stable branch usage in devstack
"""

Could you add these instructions here as well:
  manila/doc/source/devref/development-environment-devstack.rst


Also, it doesn't specifically have to be a stable branch, it can be any git ref from the source you're going to clone manila's repository from, If you wanted to use this particular change (456168) and patchset (1) from OpenStack's git server, you could use:

  enable_plugin manila https://git.openstack.org/openstack/manila  refs/changes/68/456168/1


If it isn't clear, 
 refs/changes/68/456168/1
 68 - Last 2 digits of the change number
(this is the way upstream Zuul builds its references 
when it gets code from review.openstack.org)
 456168 - The change number
 1 - Patchset number

priorities/train-priorities.rst.message:
This isn't going especially well. (Note that it's not due to Placement - see below.) There's an open spec to make some slight inroads into VGPU affinity [1], but it's more of a retrofit, not taking advantage of Placement as this theme suggests.

What we really needed was progress on NUMA modeling via placement, possibly by resurrecting this spec [2], but that hasn't happened.

I hope to make some time on the side during this release to experiment with modeling just PCPU, VCPU, MEMORY_MB, and VGPU resources via nested providers representing NUMA nodes. But whatever the result, it won't land in Train.

 [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650963/
 [2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/552924/

> This isn't going especially well. (Note that it's not due to
 > Placement - see below.) There's an open spec to make some slight
 > inroads into VGPU affinity [1], but it's more of a retrofit, not
 > taking advantage of Placement as this theme suggests.
 > 

Yup, eventually I abandoned it after 3 months.

 > What we really needed was progress on NUMA modeling via placement,
 > possibly by resurrecting this spec [2], but that hasn't happened.
 > 

The problem is that the spec deadline was in 2 weeks after abandoning the other spec so I hadn't time to revisit [2].
That said, we'll take some time in Train for working on some  WIP changes for it after Train-3.

 > I hope to make some time on the side during this release to
 > experiment with modeling just PCPU, VCPU, MEMORY_MB, and VGPU
 > resources via nested providers representing NUMA nodes. But
 > whatever the result, it won't land in Train.
 > 
 > [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650963/
 > [2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/552924/

We have merged the cpu-resources spec [1] in its much-simplified form as discussed at the PTG. Two separate, parallel efforts at the code have already been started [2]. Both apparently have separate merits and the end result will likely be a convergence of the two streams [3].

One of the simplifications made on the above spec was removing the case where a single VM could get both VCPU and PCPU resources. This use case is addressed by a separate, dependent spec [4]. At this time (just after spec freeze) the spec is not approved, though it stands a chance of being granted a spec freeze exception with some strict provisos as outlined in the blueprint whiteboard [5].

 [1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/cpu-resources.html
 [2] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:bp/cpu-resources
 [3] https://youtu.be/3OOF0FpKiYk?t=23
 [4] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668656/
 [5] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Hm, what did we mean by "additional"?

I think this relates to the ability for outside agents to ask Nova to track resources outside of Nova's purview, and allocate them via Placement during scheduling. To this end, we've approved "provider config files" [1]. Implementation is not yet started, but will be based on some old [2] and older [3] PoC code.

 [1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/provider-config-file.html

L3 agent could have more than one external network, but a router should have only one. You should retrieve all external networks from this agent and see if the router external one is in this set.
We talked this last night in l3 meeting, IMO, there is no relationship between external network and L3 agent now. So this check is not needed. Thoughts?

This removed code was try to get external_network_id from neutron-server. On neutron server this function is in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/b303f4409ea270d53866c7e296aa76d6b603ead8/neutron/db/external_net_db.py#L146 - as You can see it don't returns external network id which is set to the router. It tries to find all networks set as external and expects that there will be only one such network always. That is not true now of course as we can have many external networks.
Also on neutron-server side, it seems that there is no way to have more than one external network plugged. If You will try to set second gateway for router, it will update router and replace gateway with new one (if it's possible).

So I'm not sure if we need any additional check here TBH but maybe I'm missing something
